I wasn’t going to answer until I saw that Marco Pereira is totally misrepresenting Stephen Hawking (and doesn’t allow comments), when he says this: “To say that since there was no time, there was no physics and no rules is the same as saying God made it…:)” Besides the fact this this is just a subjective assertion, neither Hawking nor any other actual cosmologist (which, I note, Pereira is not) has ever said such a thing. What Hawking said was that the laws break down at the point of the Big Bang, and that is not at all like saying that “there was no physics and no rules”. What it is saying is more like that “existence” underwent a phase change, so that from this side of things we can’t look back and get a clue of what happened before (and Pereira, with an actual credential in Physical Chemistry, ought to recognize a phase change when he sees it!). In reality, saying that “time did not exist before the Big Bang” is an over-reach, which Hawking really recognizes when he says that the laws break down: if the laws break down, that means we have no basis on which to know if time didn’t exist or not. On the other side of the phase change, time might have flowed as we know it, or there might be a different dimension which turned into time, or there might be some other time-like dimension — indeed for it to be “existence” as we understand it, there must have been some sort of time-like dimension since existence as we understand it requires duration, which means time or something like it. Hossein Javadi cited a more pertinent Hawking quote: “Events before the Big Bang, are simply not defined, because there’s no way one could measure what happened at them”. Another way of putting this is that to even speak of “events” before the Big Bang is meaningless, since events as we understand them require duration and extension, which means time and at least two physical dimensions; and to speak of “before” the Big Bang is equally meaningless unless we assume that some time-like dimension was in operation the word “before” has no meaning (a far better term is “prior to”, which sounds like time but doesn’t require that). So “How could the Big Bang possibly have happened?” We don’t know. We can’t see “beyond” or “before” or even into the very moment of the Bang, so all we have is speculation. The only hope we have other than mathematical metaphysics (e.g. string ‘theory’) at this point is the notions of “branes”, because that conjecture at least offers the possibility of being tested, since it points to events which should have consequences in this universe, though unfortunately even if the concept is correct we may never get to see the evidence of such an event. So “God did it” is at least as likely as an eternal multiverse or something, because due to the fact that the laws do break down at that point we just have no clue.

The question of TIME is both a deeply physical and philosophical one. What is time? Most folks would say on its most basic level, that time is a series of “causal” events that occur in sequence. A clock tics … tic … tic … tic … tic. If you asked, “would time pass if there was no one or no way to measure it, our logic would demand that we still answer, “YES”. Surely, time does not need us to measure it, to exist on its own. What if we had no clocks? So what? Time would still pass, wouldn’t it? It is an inherent part of our physical world. We could for example, explain that somewhere, some event is ALWAYS occurring in the universe, then another event is occurring, then another one and so on. Lets’ say these events are the rate of inflation in the universe, or the vibrations of atoms. Somewhere in space, an atom is vibrating over time. Whether we are watching it or not, it is still vibrating. The atom itself is recording the passage of time. We don’t need to time the vibrations. They are doing a nice job on their own. Under this logic, then time passes in our universe if there is even one atom in the universe vibrating somewhere to measure it. How fast is time passing? We all thought we knew that. Logically, time passes at the same rate everywhere. Then along came Einstein. He realized that the tick of a clock or the vibration of a single atom is not the same everywhere. The rate at which a tick of time passes, apparently depends on whether the measuring device is moving THROUGH SPACE, and how fast. Take that lonely atom. If it is moving at speed X through physical space, then time passes at one rate for it. If that atom moves through space at a different speed, then time passes at a different rate for it. The faster through space the measuring device moves, the slower the passage of time becomes. In the case of a vibrating atom, if we send it flying through the universe at close to light speed, it will vibrate “slower”. According to Physicists, if the atom could reach light speed, it would stop vibrating entirely, turn into energy and be frozen in suspended animation (something no material object can ever achieve, due to the laws of special relativity, which is another whole ball of wax). What would happen if that vibrating atom did somehow, stop vibrating? What if it was the only atom in the universe, and all motion within it came to a stop? Would time still pass? How could the universe know? There would be nothing to measure its passage … no clock … no vibrating atoms … no movement at all! However, even if there was not a single atom in existence, space itself would still be inflating .. getting bigger … tic … tic … tic. Time does not need atoms to be measured by events in our universe. In trying to imagine that scenario, logic does let me envision the idea of total suspended animation. Nothing moves. No ticks occur. I could almost be satisfied claiming that time can “stand still”, because there is nothing to measure its passage. Yet … in my logic, I would still “feel” that time was passing at some rate or another, “somewhere”. I was just not able to measure it. This is particularly true regarding our universe, the Big Bang and the concept of the Multiverse. What do Physicists conceptualize when they consider the Big Bang, and what may have come before it? Prior to the Big Bang, they claim that our entire universe was confined to a tiny “infinitely small” dot called a “Singularity”. In imagining that “thing”, some of them are forced to claim through mathematics that all energy, all matter, and even space itself was inside that singularity dot. The Physics apparently demands it. Yet, how can anyone visualize infinity? If that claim is true, then our Universe apparently existed as something (a Singularity), suspended somewhere else but occupying no space at all, with no passage of time … forever! How can anyone visualize Forever? Forever is a LONG TIME. It exists for all Eternity, for God’s sake! Worse, that Singularity reportedly had characteristics. It was HOT! At the moment it “woke up” and turned into the Big Bang expansion, that Singularity was supposedly trillions of degrees in temperature, FILLED with something scientists call “vacuum energy”, cosmic foam, Higgs fields, Quantum virtual particles, cosmic strings …. There are lots of names for it. Then, something happened! Somehow, our “singularity”, existing somewhere in an infinitely small space without the passage of time, existing with all those characteristics, BEGAN! It inflated and expanded in volume at much faster-than-light speeds. At that precise moment, time began to tick in our new universe? The clock started. Dark Energy, Dark matter, vacuum energy, 3-dimensional space, cosmic inflation, cooling of energy to form quarks and leptons, the coalescing of something called the four “Forces” of the universe … it all began with that event some 13.8 billion years ago. Once the Big Bang expansion began, there were “things” in the new universe to record the passage of time. Quarks appeared and began spinning. Particles came together. It does not matter how fast or slow time passed, it is enough that something was now present to measure time’s passage. So, scientists are happy to state that time began with the Big Bang. Well, back to the moment before the Big Bang. There is NO logic that can be called upon to claim that our universe’s Singularity existed as an infinite “nothing”, for all of infinity … then suddenly .. something happened to it to cause it to expand. The evidence for the Big Bang is very solid. Apparently, our universe did begin 13.8 billion years ago. However, every ounce of common sense demands that we picture our Singularity as existing SOMEWHERE ELSE before it broke out. Cosmologists are also frustrated with the claims, and ask the same questions. A growing number of them have proposed an answer. Maybe, our universe’s Singularity existed as a tiny “dot” within a much much larger environment … a MULTIVERSE … a place filled with space of its own, matter, energy, other universes, and other Singularities. Maybe we are but one of a countless number of other ‘bubble universes’, existing in some larger space, side by side, a space spanning mind-boggling distances. In that vision, there would be ENORMOUS NUMBERS of other universes. Some Cosmologists banter around that the Multiverse may be “Infinite” in size. That just doesn’t cut it. Infinity cannot be envisioned. How can something, constituting some concept of physical space, go on forever … never stopping … forever … with time passing within it forever … with no beginning of time or space or energy or matter … and no edges … and no boundaries … no ending … no dimensions? How could matter and energy be infinite in substance? Where did it all come from? How could it not have come into existence at some time in the past? The very idea is nonsensical, yet Physicists toss it around as if it were established fact. Likewise, the concept of a Finite Universe is also impossible. How could the Multiverse be finite? That means it had a beginning. What was present before the beginning? Where did all the stuff of the Multiverse come from? It just cannot appear from NOTHING. There had to be a start … an origin, yet what was around before that start? Frankly, both the finite and infinite concepts of universe and multiverses are impossible, yet one of them must be true. It is enough to lose sleep over … I’ll tell you. If it exists in some form or another, would time pass in the Multiverse? Presumably, it would! As envisioned, things would be going on in the Multiverse that would serve as measuring devices, to measure time’s passage. The rate of time’s passage might be very different than in our universe, but time itself … would surely pass, provided there was something happening … some series of events … some step by step “vibration of an atom” to measure it. Other Big Bangs would explode outward. Some bubble universes would die. Things would occur! If this theory has any validity at all, then my answer to your question is that time DID exist and DID PASS before our Big Bang. It just passed somewhere else, in the Multiverse. Our universe’s Singularity, containing all of its own space, energy and potential matter, was trapped in suspended animation for some unknown passage of time, and did not start its own ticking clock going until the moment it began inflating. What of the “future”? According to popular theories, our universe has three fates, far in the future. It can expand forever. If so, then time will presumably tick in it forever, or at least until all movement, vibration and ways of measuring time’s passage disappear. At that time, perhaps our dead cold universe will enter a new phase of suspended animation. Time in it will stop ticking, but time outside of it, within the bigger Multiverse, will still go on. Fate 2 is to have gravity reverse inflation and cause the Big Crunch. If that happened, then the universe would presumably contract back down to a new Singularity. Cosmologists would claim that time would stop passing in it, until and if the Universe exploded again in a new Big Bang. However, if the Multiverse exists, time would still be passing in it. Fate 3 is the Big Rip … our universe inflates so fast that all of its matter comes apart, turning back into photons of energy, cosmic foam, virtual particles, cosmic strings, etc. We would not form a new Singularity … we would sort of blend into whatever is out there beyond our own universe of energy and matter … possibly the very stuff the Multiverse is made of. If that occurs, then again, time would still pass in the Multiverse. What if there is no Multiverse? Then, we are “sucking wind” so to speak. Both Infinity and Finite concepts of time are impossible. Energy cannot be created. This should give you a sense of how elementary energy is. Energy is the only original stuff that ever was; no one could put it there, it has no ulterior source, it is the simplest substance in the world. Before the beginning of time, there was only energy. Imagine a body so archaic that it lacks time, space, matter or gravitation. It is an energy singularity made of uncountable energy packets we know as quanta. Look now at the possibilities open to energy. A “false vacuum” is an unstable state that spontaneously changes to a more stable state through “bubble nucleation”. A bubble spreads at a speed close to light with walls that have “surface tension”. This looks very much like the creation of space. More quanta inside the bubble self-assemble into the dozen elementary particles we know and further aggregate into matter. The energy-matter density inside the bubble gives space its geometric property, gravitation. This is how you produce a Big Bang out of a stock of the simplest and primordial substance in the world, energy. Here is more. What was before the Big Bang? Before the Big Bang there was an energy singularity with no space, time, matter or gravitation, and zero density. There is a way to “see” this primeval body; it cannot disappear without causing every object spawned by it to also vanish. By lacking spacetime the energy singularity appears to have existed “then”, continues to exist now, and will remain undisturbed in its “place” even if our universe disappears. Why do cosmologists disagree on what existed before the Big Bang? The tested instrument that made the Big Bang a necessity is of no application before the very beginning. General relativity concerns space, time, mass, energy and gravitation, but the theory says these phenomena debuted together 13.8 billion years ago, throwing no light on what may have existed before such a bizarre epoch. Events prior to the Big Bang are deemed to be unobservable, their information lost to us. Even in the face of such impediments, cosmologists lack no ideas on what may have caused the universe into being. Scenarios range from a universe undergoing an endless cycle of birth, collapse and rebirth; a mechanism—eternal inflation—bringing into being a myriad of universes, making ours a part of a “multiverse”; the idea that the universe is confined to a sort of membrane inside a higher dimensional space—the “hyperspace”—and many others, including the possibility that “nothing” split in two opposite halves so that the total energy of the universe is zero (0=1-1), have been advanced. Why have physicists never proposed a singularity made purely of energy? Physicists are concerned solely with their subject matter, persuaded that physics is a senior science taking precedence over the rest. Because this is also the general opinion, they overlooked the known solution to the only other two “origins” dilemmas. Evolution, an old subject. Science first stumbled with an “origins” mystery in the second half of the 19th century. A couple of English biologists faced a seemingly impossible question: were current lifeforms created in their present shape or were they descended from earlier ancestors? What they found was evidence for an evolution. A series of slightly varying creatures, increasingly fewer and more rustic as one got into the past, produced the astonishing variety of earth’s life—science now places a single cell as the ancestor to all modern life. The ensuing scandal was to be made worse by one of the two Victorians who clung to the matter in regard to humans. Did we also descend from more primitive animals? He said yes and devoted a book to examine the issue at length. What about the top question, the emergence of life itself? Before the creation of the first living creature there was only ordinary matter, so Darwin envisioned life arising out of self-assembling organic compounds in a “warm little pond” bathed in heat, light and electricity. The key to all “origins” conundrums. Darwin showed how discontinuous, seemingly incongruous qualities emerge from an unbroken chain of events. His method to the origin of new phenomena was to look in the preexistent, simpler environment. By following it he got the right answers, twice. Humans originated from primates and life from organic compounds ultimately made of ordinary matter. Where the arrow of simplicity points to. The straightforward mechanism of evolution forces us to look for some simpler, preexisting body capable of spawning the entire universe. It should have known traits; it should be completely “dark” in our eyes and yet very visible if properly looked for; its constituent stuff should be very ordinary and yet capable of taking many different shapes. The law of conservation of energy. The law states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed. By this law there should be an initial inventory of energy to create the universe. Energy lacks corporeality and yet it is a real physical property. As a conserved quantity, energy is also unaffected by time—Einstein showed that time and space are part of the same continuum, spacetime, so anything alien to space is also so to time. Lacking corporeality and time does not prevent energy to transform itself into other, even tangible, forms. The mass-energy equivalence principle. Einstein showed that mass and energy are equivalent. Initially just a convenient theoretical tool, experimental physicists found practical ways to use this principle to transform mass and energy into each other. Atomic bombs and reactors have been made to release huge quantities of energy. In the other end, protons brought to a speed close to light are made to clash in frontal collisions to produce much more massive particles than those of the protons involved. More complex, tridimensional mass, abounding in uncountable chemical varieties, is made of confined energy moving at the speed of light. The energy of the void. By the end of the last century, cosmologists found that the universe is expanding at an accelerated rate. A low-density, “dark” energy, first proposed by Einstein as a “cosmological constant”, is doing the pushing. It has been referred to as the “energy of space itself”, the “energy of the void”, or “vacuum energy”. There is a catch. As the universe expands, in order to keep the thrust constant, more and more space has to be created. At the scale of the whole universe, energy is not conserved; more energy is coming from an unknown source. The other space, the quantum vacuum. Quantum mechanics is the other general physical theory. It describes nature at the scale of atoms, nuclei and subatomic particles. It is inconsistent with general relativity because quantum phenomena have no equivalent in general relativity. One fine example is the uncertainty principle. Quantum field theory treats the void as populated by fields that never go away. The uncertainty principle forbids knowing with precision the value of a field at a point in space. If a point in space were to lack particles, the field’s precise value would be known—it would have zero energy. The vacuum is thus populated by quantum fluctuations, virtual particles that pop into and out of existence. Because their contribution is however positive, the quantum vacuum has energy—even infinite energy. Unlike the constant density of the “dark” energy, in the quantum realm, the smaller the scale, the greater the vacuum energy density—as smaller wavelengths traduce into higher frequencies. Calculations jump many zeroes when going from the scale of atoms to that of nuclei to that of a thousandth of nuclei. Physicists stop at the Planck scale because beyond this scale existing theories make no sense. At this point the vacuum energy density reaches 110^112 ergs/cm3. The measured density of dark energy is 10^-8 ergs/cm3. There is a gap of 120 zeroes between the energy of the space at the cosmic scale and that of space at the quantum scale. This disparity alone should tell physicists that the two vacuums do not refer to the same phenomenon. The energy singularity. The incredibly thick energy barrier—much denser than matter—surrounding the universe in the direction of the very small is the energy singularity. This body is so archaic that it lacks spacetime; this is how it managed to exist “before” the Big Bang. Since gravitation is a geometric property of spacetime, the huge energy of this singularity does not have any gravitational effects on our universe. From the energy singularity to the universe. Starting with the energy singularity, the first step to produce the universe is the creation of spacetime: a bubble, membrane, higher-dimensional world “inside” the dimensionless singularity, driven by inflation, a false vacuum, or some other spontaneous reaction of the original medium, such as a “quantum fluctuation”. The accompanying event is the leakage of some of the—very simple—bundles of energy into the new medium. The space-less quanta then assemble into the 64 known species of elementary particles. Thanks to the second-generation phenomenon of spacetime, quanta can further bond and aggregate into the tridimensional arrays we know as matter. Quantum phenomena and why no one understands them. The simplest parts of a structure cannot disappear without causing it to also vanish. It follows that if the most elementary pieces of our universe come from the pre-Big Bang era, we should be able to confirm this, today. By taking a close look at the smallest chunks of matter—elementary particles, atoms and molecules—physicists have “seen” them dissolve into waves. The particles reappear after some sort of interaction, usually a collision with a macroscopic object, an event called a “measurement”. Much of this process is actually unobservable; the waves are mathematically modelled and there is a strong indication that they are just “probability waves”—a piece of math—describing unphysical objects that exist at best in some sublayer of reality. We have problem dealing with this other, subtler layer of reality because our mind is not well suited to ponder events occurring in the absence of space and time. Violations of ordinary logic by quantum phenomena. Nontechnical accounts of quantum phenomena have provided us with illustrations such as the following. Quantum objects exist as superpositions of different states; they can be in more than one place at the same time. An electron within an atom can jump from one place to another without crossing the intervening space. Quantum objects can tunnel through barriers. If one wants to know the precise position of a particle then one cannot know its precise momentum and vice versa. Quantum objects going from point A to point B follow all possible paths simultaneously. Entangled particles can interact instantly across space. One cannot observe anything without disturbing it. In these examples the concepts of space, time and corporeality are violated. The reason is that quantum objects lack space—and hence corporeality—whether immersed in space or matter. If freely flying when “measured”—disturbed—by a collision or obstacle, such objects behave weirdly. Depending on the type of interaction, they can show wave or particle-like characteristics, and the measurement of the whole set of their properties by classical standards, as if they were true particles, is unattainable. The origin of probability in quantum mechanics. Quantum formalism—its mathematical apparatus—cannot predict the outcome of single interactions such as the precise spot where an electron fired against a screen will appear. Rather, it provides the probabilities to observe one of the possible outcomes. The predicted distribution of probabilities appears only after many runs of the same experiment. Why? There is no equivalent between a “non-object” suspended in a space-less sphere and one existing in space and time. Imagine a cat posing for us, in the dark. At one time it will be standing and at a different one, sitting. It can be licking its right paw or the left one. It can face us, show us one of its sides or appear tail first. All these are valid “configurations” for the cat to be in. Suppose now that we have a light that lets us take a glance at the cat each time we flash it. With each flash we will see a single “configuration” of the cat. In no case we will be able to anticipate it, all we will know is that we will see a valid configuration. The many states of the cat—its entire shape or structure—will be evident only after many flashes. Entanglement. The phenomenon of entanglement is especially illustrative on how a space-less object behaves in spacetime. Two electrons are entangled if the properties of each depend on the properties of the other—the pair is said to share the same wavefunction. For instance, if one is in a “spin up” configuration, the other will have the other, “spin down”. While freely flying they are supposed to be in a superposition of the two states—really an unphysical state foreign to spatial traits. Now, it is possible to send the electrons in opposite directions. Suppose that a measurement is performed on one of them. If the outcome is “spin down”, we will find the partner in the opposite, “spin up” configuration. In other words, the particles communicate instantly across space. Why? The reason is that their primary bond is more elementary, so it supersedes their spatial relationship. Conclusion. Four singularities: the energy singularity, the universe, life, and humans. Biologists use the term “singularity” to refer to events or properties that are single or unique, for instance, landmarks in the history of life. Speaking from a broader perspective, Spanish biochemist Juan Oró says that there are three large singularities in the world: the universe, life, and humans. The problem with this statement is that there are two mutually inconsistent physical theories competing to describe Oró’s first singularity, the universe. The solution to this conundrum first requires understanding that the problem of the origin of the universe belongs in the same category as the other two solved by Darwin. Once the necessity of a simpler body is realized, its nature is easy to elaborate. What follows is the question of how such a space-less, timeless body fits in the framework of science. You perhaps need to rephrase the question. The Big Bang theory is a theory based on General Relativity that explains that the universe expands (as derived from GR itself and observed by the redshift-distance relation by Hubble) and therefore in the past was smaller, hotter and denser. The Big Bang theory itself does not say what started the expansion or what was before. The Big Bang theory does NOT state that the universe started as an infinitely dense point (singularity). That is something most people don’t quite understand and equate the ‘big bang theory’ (the currently accepted standard model of cosmology) with the idea that everything started with a singularity. The last idea is wrong, and here is why. The model only takes into account General Relativity and ignores quantum mechanics, so other forces/interactions, like electro-magnetism, strong and weak nuclear force, are completely ignored. Such an approximation works as long as all the other forces are comparitively small (as compared to gravitation). For the weak and strong nuclear force this is the case as long as distances are large enough. For electro-magnetism (which itself extends infinite range, like gravity, but is much stronger then gravity) the approximation is good as long as at that distance scale matter is electrical neutral and thus the resultant electric/magnetic forces can be neglected. NB. There is a different cosmological idea, the electric universe, which claims that electrical and magnetic forces do not cancel even at large scales, and therefore the big bang model is wrong. Electric universe theory might be at least in part correct for the claim that electric and magnetic forces have more influence on galaxy/star and planetary formation as previously understood, but the claim that electric/magnetic forces dominate the evolution of the whole universe (instead of gravity) is supposedly wrong. The assumptions on which the cosmological model in the big bang theory is based however break down near the point of singularity when distance scales become arbitrarily small, and that is why the model can no longer claim to be correct without taking into account conrtributions of the other forces. But there is no theory at hand that combines both GR and QM. That is a topic of active research and theory construction (loop quantum gravity, string theory/M theory). So, what started the expansion of the universe? An explenation that is widely accepted is that of inflationary cosmology, that explains that before the expansion of the universe there was a very brief period of exponential expansion due to repulsive gravity. Inflation ends because the field that causes the exponential expansion decays. Inflation can explain the homogeneity with the right amount of fluctuations (stretched out quantum fluctuations) to explain stucture formation (galaxies, etc.), why the density of the universe is so very close to critical density (if only a tiny bit less dense, the universe would be almost empty, if only a tiny bit denser, the universe would have already collapsed on itself). The question about "what was before the big bang" also is left to pre-Big Bang theories, of which inflationary theory is still the dominant explenation. Inflationary cosmology also predicted gravitational waves, which in the near future will be observed.

First, a bit of meta-answering. This question has the following form, which is quite common here at Quora: “If [premise] then why [impossible or unreasonable thing] ?” Questions of this form usually have one of two answers: a) The premise is false. b) The impossible or unreasonable thing actually never happened. Since we can observe the universe around us, it is safe to say that it happened. So we can conclude that there is something wrong with the premise that space and time did not exist before the big bang. The big bang is just a term for a time when conditions in the universe were so different from what we see today that we cannot confidently predict what came before it. That does not mean that space and time didn’t exist. It just means that what we have learned about physics by observing the universe around us has not given us enough information to understand the universe back then. Using what we know about physics, we can extrapolate backward, to a time when the matter and energy we see today was very compact and very hot. But at some point, it all appears to have been so compact and hot that we can’t make confident predictions about how it would have behaved. And we can’t predict what state it was in prior to that state. Newton’s physics gave us a pretty good understanding of how things behave at everyday speeds, but it didn’t make good predictions about how things behave at very high speeds or very small scales. For that, we needed a new way of looking at things - Einstein’s physics. But even that still doesn’t tell us enough to make good predictions about how things behave under very high temperature and pressure. For that, we need to make more observations of the highest temperatures and pressures that we can study - which is where things like the Large Hadron Collider come in. We’re still learning. The big bang represents the limits of our understanding of the universe - which is not the same thing as the limits of the universe. It makes no sense to leap from “we don’t know what happened earlier” to “there was nothingness earlier.” There was something. We’re not sure what it was like, but we’re investigating.

To begin, let’s step around the human-centred experience of time. Rather, time is an ordering of states of the universe - what happens first and what happens next. We don’t need to worry about complicated discussions relating to relativity and entropy to consider an answer to the question. So we are referring to an ontic ordering, meaning it is about the order of existence, in particular, states of the universe (and everything). Hence, in this context we are asking for something that existed ontically prior to the Big Bang. We are looking for first-cause. The question pivots on philosophical (metaphysical) reasoning because anything ontologically prior to the Planck time (the shortest sensible unit of time) is not a question that physics can answer - it is outside the discipline. First-cause was argued to be necessary, meaning essentially inescapable, by Aristotle. He said, and others agree (e.g. Leibniz’s principle of sufficient reason) that everything has a cause. However, he noted that this led to an infinite regress that would mean there would be no way for things to start. He therefore supposed there must be an uncaused cause, an unmoved mover, a cause that was the cause of itself. This sounds a little odd, but in a more contemporary setting, he is saying there must be some condition of the world that always was, and always will be. Such a cause exists independently from time. It would exist at the origin, indeed, in a sense it would be the origin. It must have brought the world into existence, including space and time. So the Big Bang’s initiation is independent of time. There is, however, a movement in fundamental theory to question the fundamental nature of time (and space).  For pretty much forever, we've kind of assumed space and time have been there, and constructed a theory of physics--something to explain the existence of matter and energy, their properties, and their evolution--on top of them.  Physicists, inspired by the question of "where did our universe come from?" are now beginning to ask questions about whether it might be more true that time and space are 'emergent' properties of our universe, rather than a fundamental quality of reality. Fundamentally, the answer to whether or not time is emergent or fundamental (and, if emergent, how it emerges) necessarily rests on understanding we just don't have--a theory of quantum gravity.  The universe near its very beginning is simply outside the realm of validity of the known physical laws--just like the singularity of a black hole, it's too compact for our theory of gravity and too dense for our theory of particle physics.  The final answer to this question, then, awaits such a theory, though that doesn't mean physicists aren't hard at work coming up with ideas.
